item.title: Psychosocial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Psychosocial Hypothesis in Ufology ðŸ”—

The psychosocial hypothesis (PSH) in ufology suggests that some UFO reports are best explained by psychological or social factors rather than extraterrestrial origins. It contrasts with the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH) and is favored by UFO researchers in the UK and France. Proponents view UFOs as an interesting subject for study, even with skepticism.

Origin ðŸ”—

The term “psychosocial hypothesis” gained prominence in English UFO literature in 1984, influenced by French UFO controversies sparked by Michel Monnerie’s challenge to the ETH. Magonia magazine played a key role in popularizing the term. Peter Rogerson’s adoption of the term marked a shift away from paranormal explanations towards normal psychological processes influenced by cultural myths and social conditioning. Writers associated with Magonia had been exploring alternatives to the ETH since 1968, driven by the belief that it failed to account for high strangeness cases. Roger Sandell’s research on a 1905 Welsh UFO wave led him to conclude that UFO reports were part of a larger complex of ghost stories and religious visions. Peter Rogerson advocated for a search for historical antecedents of UFO rumors and the social factors driving UFO flaps and social panics, noting a relationship between UFO waves and times of radical social change.

Science Fiction Aspects of the UFO Mythos ðŸ”—

Bertrand MÃ©heust’s study of science fiction parallels to UFO mythology revealed numerous similarities between UFO experience narratives and pre-1947 science fiction literature. These parallels include wondrous effects like invisible force-fields, teleportation, and engine-stopping rays, as well as humanoid motives for visiting Earth. Michel Monnerie integrated Meheust’s study into his historical critique of UFO mythology. Michel Meurger expanded Meheust’s thesis with a compendium of parallels. Jacques Vallee noted electromagnetic effects associated with UFOs in earlier fiction. Researchers have explored the cultural backstories to various alien types, including Grays, insectoids, and reptoids.

The Saucer Rumor ðŸ”—

The psychosocial approach helped solve the mystery of why flying saucers are the dominant shape in UFO reports. Martin Kottmeyer discovered that the “flying saucer” label originated from a misinterpretation of Kenneth Arnold’s 1947 sighting. Arnold described the objects’ motion as erratic, “like a saucer if you skip it across the water,” but the reporter misinterpreted this as describing the objects’ shape. This mistake shaped the UFO phenomenon for decades, influencing film imagery, saucer photography, UFO illustration, contactee tales, and abduction experiences.

Flaps of Flying Phantoms ðŸ”—

Early researchers attempted to correlate UFO flaps with Mars’ proximity, but these predictions failed. British researchers shifted focus to pre-1947 “waves,” examining social, religious, political, and scientific backgrounds. Nigel Watson researched a Marchâ€“May 1909 panic involving German airships spying on Britain. Phantom airship flaps were cataloged in various locations, often accompanied by rumors of foreign spies. By the 1930s, phantom airships were replaced by phantom aeroplanes. Researchers have experimented with variations in these explanations, such as the 1905 Wales flap occurring during a time of rapid social change. Researchers generally reject explanations involving mass hysteria, preferring to discuss flaps as collective delusions maintained by rumor and gossip.

The Modern Myth of Jung ðŸ”—

Carl Gustav Jung’s essay Flying Saucers: A Modern Myth of Things Seen in the Skies is considered a foundational work of the PSH. While some argue that Jung also considered the ETH, Jung himself refuted claims that he believed UFOs were physically real. He emphasized the psychological significance of the UFO phenomenon, regardless of its objective reality.

item.title: Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting
item.description:
Nash-Fortenberry UFO Sighting ðŸ”—

The Nash-Fortenberry UFO sighting occurred on July 14, 1952, when two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported seeing eight UFOs in a tight echelon formation over Chesapeake Bay in Virginia.

Description ðŸ”—

Two commercial pilots, William B. Nash and William H. Fortenberry, reported observing eight UFOs flying in formation over Chesapeake Bay, Virginia. Ufologists highlight the pilots’ observation allowed for measurements of the objects’ motion and size relative to known landmarks. The sighting was reportedly corroborated by independent ground witnesses. Project Blue Book listed the case as an “unknown.”

Explanations ðŸ”—

Donald Howard Menzel suggested the pilots might have seen distorted ground lights due to haze or fireflies trapped in the cockpit window. Steuart Campbell proposed the sighting was a mirage of Venus.

  3. Steuart Campbell’s book, The UFO Mystery Solved, where he suggests the sighting was a mirage of Venus.
